instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>... WTF?
threads.message:
No backlight board, board came to me with liquid damage, however very minimal, and the spill seemed to have not contact anything critical.

Backlight circuit has no damage, neither does display connector.

0V on backlight output, started to diagnose with good working screen. I would get image, just no backlight. <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> would not open, 12.6V all across the board, <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> would not drop either. I was inspecting <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, and <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>, when I guess from me touching either one (not sure which) <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> had a fit, and literally caught fire, and exploded...

The 4 pads (6,5,1,2) are now exposed, and I can peel back that layer... edit (<CAPACITOR>C7701</CAPACITOR>, no stuff, pin 1 is gone)

Pretty f*kd. However testing with a multimeter shows no shorts, and continuity is still fine with those pads. Im almost certain I can repair this board, however Id really like some advice on how to proceed with this.

My questions are why did <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> just implode out of the blue and what could this mean. Everything else reads correctly compared to working board. Could L7710 be a culprit (although looks completely fine).

Funniest part is that when I was testing this with my power supply, I saw the amperage spike to over 3.8A, shut it off, damage was done, and F7700 could not be bothered by this. Fuse is still good!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>... WTF?
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> can explode only if the current find a way to flow through it to ground.
Did you check diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>?
Do it w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>... WTF?
threads.message: Thank you for the help, <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> showed low on pin 2 in diode mode, read about 0.150V. Definitely was shorted and found <CAPACITOR>C7710</CAPACITOR> was shorting the rail. Thank you!
